Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election saw former Interior Minister Leonid Dzapshba announcing his intention to run for president (1). The European Union does not recognize the constitutional and legal framework of the election (3). The election was held for 49 out of 60 seats in the Seanad (2). The election sparked violent protests and the resignation of former president Raul Khajimba (4). The international community does not recognize the election (7). Aslan Bzhania was declared the winner of the election by the President of Russia (9).

Timeline.Text: Former Interior Minister of Abkhazia Leonid Dzapshba announces his intention to run for president in the 2020 election.
Voters in the Abkhazian presidential election rate housing and health as the most important issues in deciding how to vote.
Ashraf Ghani is declared the winner of Afghanistan's presidential election, five months after the poll took place.
Bernie Sanders officially wins the Utah presidential primary.
A re-run of the presidential election in Abkhazia, following violent protests and the resignation of the former president, is held.
The European Union does not recognize the constitutional and legal framework of the so-called presidential elections in Abkhazia.
Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulates Aslan Bzhania on his election as President of Abkhazia.
Three confirmed cases of COVID-19 are reported in Abkhazia.

Overview.Summary: Aslan Bzhania, leader of the opposition, won the repeat presidential election in Abkhazia with over 56% of the vote (1,2,4,8). His main opponent, Adgur Ardzinba, received 35.4% of the vote (1,2,4). The two candidates united during the race, while a third candidate, Leonid Dzapshba, proposed postponing the election due to Bzhania's illness (3,7). Russia has not recognized the election (6), and Georgia has disputed the results (9). Bzhania was inaugurated as president on April 23, with former Minister of Culture Badra Gunba as Vice President (8).

Timeline.Text: The presidential election in Abkhazia takes place, with opposition leader Aslan Bzhania and former Economy Minister Adgur Ardzinba as the main candidates.
Aslan Bzhania is declared the winner of the presidential election, receiving 56.5% of the vote.
Adgur Ardzinba concedes defeat and congratulates Aslan Bzhania on his victory.
The OSW reports on the election and the success of the opposition in Abkhazia.
Aslan Bzhania is inaugurated as the new President of Abkhazia.
Former Economy Minister Adgur Ardzinba resigns from his position.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election (date: 2020-03-22) resulted in the victory of Aslan Bzhania (3,5) after the decision of the Supreme Court to annul the results of the 2019 election (1). This election was held for 49 out of 60 seats (2) and had a turnout of 71.6% (5). In neighboring Afghanistan, a different presidential election was held (4). In Malawi, the 2019 election was annulled and a new vote was ordered (8). Meanwhile, in the United States, Pete Buttigieg dropped out of the 2020 presidential election (9). The coronavirus pandemic had not yet affected the three de facto breakaway states of the South Caucasus, including Abkhazia (10).

Timeline.Text: Aslan Bzhania is declared the winner of the Abkhazian presidential election.
The Malawi presidential election is annulled and a new vote is ordered.
Pete Buttigieg drops out of the 2020 Democratic primary.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election is a controversial topic, with many countries not recognizing it as legitimate (3,6,7,8,9,10). The elected president, Aslan Bzhania, previously ran for the same position in 2019 but lost (3). The election was held on March 22, 2020 (1,2,3,5,6,7,10) and resulted in the re-election of incumbent president Faure Gnassingb\u00e9 (4). There are ongoing discussions about the need for bilateral talks between Georgia and Abkhazia (5,6,7).

Overview.Summary: In January 2020, the nomination process for candidates for the 2020 Abkhazian presidential election began (1). The election was set to take place on March 22, 2020, but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic (6). The election involved three candidates, with the two favorites being Adgur Ardzinba and Aslan Bzhania (6). The international community did not recognize the election as legitimate (9, 10). The election also sparked protests and the resignation of former president Raul Khajimba (3). A special commission was formed to test the knowledge of candidates, which led to controversy among social media users (4). The election highlights the ongoing political tensions between Abkhazia and Georgia, with Japan also expressing concern over the issue (10).

Timeline.Text: The nomination period for candidates for the 2020 Abkhazian presidential election begins.
Articles discussing the 2017, 2019, and upcoming 2020 Abkhazian presidential elections are categorized and published on Wikipedia.
Recent political protests and upheaval in Abkhazia lead to the resignation of President Raul Khadzhimba and the scheduling of a new election.
New requirements for presidential candidates in Abkhazia are announced, including fluency in the Abkhaz language and no dual citizenship.
All 668 university applicants from Abkhazia are accepted into Abkhazian State University without exams due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
A re-run of the 2019 Abkhazian presidential election is held, with Adgur Ardzinba and Aslan Bzhania as the two main candidates.
In light of negotiations with Russia and opposition to deeper collaboration, there is no discussion of a referendum for unification with Russia in Abkhazia.
The international community does not recognize the so-called 'presidential elections' in Abkhazia.

The Embassy of Japan in Georgia issues a statement regarding the so-called Abkhazian presidential elections, emphasizing the importance of peaceful resolution of the issue concerning Abkhazia in line with the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity of Georgia.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election took place on March 22, 2020 after the previous election was annulled and the President resigned due to protests against his presidency (1). The President does not have the power to postpone the election, it rests with Congress (3). The election in Ireland for the 33rd Dáil took place on February 8, 2020 (8). Elizabeth Warren dropped out of the 2020 presidential race on March 5, 2020 (9).

Timeline.Text: Raul Khajimba is inaugurated as President of Abkhazia and pledges to work towards a new treaty with Russia for deeper integration.
The Irish general election for the 33rd Dáil takes place on a Saturday for the first time, with all previous elections taking place on a weekday.
The Delhi elections take place, with a voter turnout of 57.06% according to the Election Commission of India.
The South Carolina Presidential Preference Primary (PPP) is held, where voters vote for their choice to be a political party's nominee for President in the general election.
Elizabeth Warren drops out of the Presidential race after a disappointing finish in the Super Tuesday primaries.
The Abkhazian Presidential election is held, after the results of the 2019 election were annulled and President Raul Khajimba resigned.
Experts warn that the coronavirus outbreak could affect the integrity of the 2020 Presidential election in the United States.
Bernie Sanders suspends his Presidential campaign, cementing his front-runner status but losing momentum in later days.
The scheduled date for the Polish presidential election, which has been postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Overview.Summary: Aslan Bzhania won the 2020 Abkhazian presidential election (1,2,3,7). He fell ill during the campaign and his party called for the election to be postponed if he could not participate (4). Bzhania appointed Ankvab as prime minister, who had previously been appointed by former president Raul Khadjimba (5). Bzhania and other candidates united in the race for president (6). The first party to nominate a candidate for the election was registered by the Central Election Committee (8). Bzhania went on a visit to Moscow after taking the oath of office as president (9). He also appointed Beslan Dzhopua as First Deputy Prime Minister and Vladimir Delba as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance (10).

Timeline.Text: Three candidates, including Aslan Bzhania, are nominated for the Abkhazian presidential election.
Aslan Bzhania falls ill during his campaign for the Abkhazian presidential election.
Aslan Bzhania wins the Abkhazian presidential election in the first round.
Aslan Bzhania takes the oath of office as President of Abkhazia.
Aslan Bzhania appoints his First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance.
The new Abkhazian cabinet is formed, including Aslan Bzhania's appointees.
Aslan Bzhania visits Moscow as his first official trip as President of Abkhazia.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election (5,6,7,8) was held on March 22 in the Republic of Abkhazia (1,2,3,4,9,10). The election was not recognized by the international community due to the disputed legal and constitutional framework (7,9,10). The election was prompted by the resignation of former president Raul Khadzhimba in January 2020 (3,4). The leading candidate, Aslan Bzhaniya, was hospitalized in Sochi prior to the election (4). The election was seen as a contradiction in the political game in Abkhazia (3).

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Abkhazian presidential election took place on March 22, following the annulment of the 2019 election results (5,16). Aslan Bzhania, leader of the opposition, won the election with a little over 56% of the vote (2,10,14). His main opponent, Adgur Ardzinba, received about 35% of the vote (2,10). The third candidate, Leonid Dzapshba, received 2.22% of the vote (16). The election was held amidst controversy and concerns about ballot tampering (17). The newly elected president was inaugurated on April 23 (14). The election proceeded despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic (19).

Timeline.Text: Presidential elections are held in the Republic of Abkhazia, following the decision of the Supreme Court to annul the results of the 2019 election on January 10 and the subsequent resignation of President Raul Khajimba.
Aslan Bzhania, leader of the united opposition in Abkhazia, wins the presidential election with over 56% of the vote.
Aslan Bzhania is inaugurated as President of Abkhazia.
Bzhania's victory is celebrated by his supporters as a win for the opposition.
